--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> The a=
dvantage of using two separate files is that your test data better
> reflec=
ts the intent of what you want to test, and you can run and
debug the
> tes=
ts in isolation from each other.
> 
> I can't think of a huge advantage of =
loading both at the same time,
unless
> you get a really big performance be=
nefit (even then, I might do the
above
> instead).
> 
>    David Saff
> 
> =
On 11/8/06, johnpitchko <john.pitchko@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hello,
> >
> > I =
am writing some tests which will test our batch load processes.
> > These p=
rocesses basically load files through our middleware and verify
> > the out=
put in Oracle.
> >
> > My question is related to best practices. In my curr=
ent situation, I
> > want to write two tests:
> > 1) is a standard operatio=
n test where it loads a file and makes sure
> > everything was sent properl=
y to Oracle.
> > 2) is a specialized test where it loads a file and checks =
to see if
> > the site code was capitalized in Oracle.
> >
> > So my questi=
on is this, should I use individual files for each test
> > (i.e., one file=
 containing many lines of site data for the first test
> > and then a seper=
ate file containing a single line with a lowercase
> > site code) and load =
each file at the start of each test, or should I
> > combine the data from =
both into a single file and load that before all
> > the tests are run (usi=
ng a @BeforeClass)?
> >
> > Thank you in advance.
> >
> >
> >
> >

ahoo! Groups Links
